Resident Evil 4 is really really good and probably the best resident evil game out there right now at least in gameplay. 

Capcom basically took everything that worked so well in Resident Evil 2 & 7, dialed up the action and gameplay by 10 while still managing to keep the iconic horror this franchise is known for. They have successfully struck the perfect balance between action packed power fantasy gameplay, and  iconic resident evil horror. This is something most studios can't achieve, yet Capcom not only did it, but also perfected it in this game.

The cut scenes, the environments, the art direction, the carefully designed details on every surface, it's all done with such surgical perfection and it's only further enhanced by the buttery smooth optimisation of this game. No stutters, No frame rate drops, not even a single bug to encountered in my entire 30 hour playthrough. Every section, level, terrain, item and location not only looks gorgeous, but plays perfectly and just like how it's supposed to. I cannot commend the people behind this engine and games enough. Truly talented tech geniuses and its their innovation that set the ground work for what has made this franchise ascend into god tier quality.

What makes this game stand out so much though is the gameplay. Third-person Blood-curdling action packed linear levels with satisfying gun play that is only further enhanced by Capcom's insane sound design. Every foot step, every gun shot, even something as small as the sound of pages turning is so detailed. When you shoot someone in the head, you feel the impact of the bullet from the sound of skin tearing and blood splatter. When you round house kick, you feel the heavy impact of leon's foot on the enemies neck from the sound of it snapping and cracking. It really brings this game to life. It is truly a technical marvel and i swear no one in this industry does sound as good as capcom does.

Its all further enhanced by the variety of weapons & upgrades in this game. There's enough here to keep a healthy level of flexibility in how you want to play. The progression system in how you upgrade your weapons is also incorporated into exploration, making it always feel rewarding and worth while. The enemies follow suit in quality, ranging from your classic terrifying big monster with dodge mechanics to a slippery assassin scorpion that intelligently uses the environment to sneak up and attack you. Many also have little twists and details that really enrich the way you can approach enemies. Villagers that hold C4's in their hand that you can shoot to blow them and their surroundings up. Infected with regenerative abilities that you need to shoot specific weak spots to kill. It's this rich variety in how you interact with the game that makes the moment to moment experience always feel new. It is what makes this franchise so iconically endlessly replayable.

The story is about what you'd expect from a capcom resident evil game. Nothing insane in narrative, but just enough lore dressing and interesting connections to umbrella to keep fans like me interested in the characters of this game and the world their in. What surprised me the most though is how hilarious the writing is. Leons dialogue in particular. It's bordering Devil may cry 5 levels of ironic but still being grounded enough to feel serious. I think the execution is the real MVP here as it's done well enough to make Leon's silly 2010 esq comments come off as charming and lovable rather than cringe and annoying. The writing really is a product of its time and i'm so happy Capcom did not touch it in this remake because i really love it.

Generally speaking, this extreme of a departure in any franchise, let alone one with horror as iconic as Resident Evil's, usually turns out to be a disappointment. But Capcom really stuck the landing here. They managed to create a satisfying action focused game whilst still having it feel like resident evil. They did it so well, infact, i might prefer this style over RE 2&7's more slow placed horror, as long as it's done well. 

And this game certainly does it extremely well. Which is why I highly recommend it.

I am here from the original Resident Evil 4 crowd, which I played on the Gamecube religiously - so I cannot say how it will be for new players that never played it. But I think it should be good.

First off I want to say this is exactly how remake should be done. The graphics are excellent, the use of contrast, lighting and shadows provides a constant moody, cinematic feel throughout as does the close-following over-the-shoulder camera. It looks fantastic. But it isn't a remaster like so many developers are cashing in on (because like fuck working for money), it is a full on re-imagining of the game. It's not just quality of life improvements like better controls and character physics, the game has been completely redesigned by today's standards. 

The action is fast paced and requires a lot of finesse. The game encourages you to be constantly moving and very aggressive (like Doom), if you stand in one spot too long or go for defence, you will be taking a one way train to fuck-town. If your hands sweat easily, like mine, then bring some tissues.

The controls feel great. I used keyboard and mouse - I increased camera sensitivity for looking (but not for aiming) so that I can turn the camera quickly without lifting the mouse. I can see what they did with the default control scheme: Q for Quickturn, E for Evade, M for Map, P for Pause - but those latter to are completely unergonomic - M and P are not reachable - remap those to something else. It also uses CTRL for commanding Ashley, again this is really awkward, especially when you use the same key for catching ammo from Luis - but I found remapping to C was perfect for this and doesn't interfere with other defaults. 

The attache case now has auto sorting which really makes it much simpler, but keeps the joy that you can't become overpowered, you gotta pack the right gear and can't get greedy with ammo and healing items. There is a wide assortment of gear keeping the game interesting and encouraging multiple playthroughs as the items are designed to be unique, truly offering a different style of play (unlike the games that give you too many options, but they are all minor stat differences: AABA, ABAA, BAAA etc). There are challenges to complete and new items to unlock. Then there are some new additions such as charms which also tweak certain variables a little, like getting more ammo of a certain type from crafting, selling certain items for more - these are totally optional and add a nice flavour from the old shooting range (which too has been overhauled and improved). 

My main criticism is that enemies do seem to be able to spawn on you or in areas you have just been and were empty. This is discussed - but I am not being paranoid, I had this happen in the Village house when you're with Luis at points where no entry was possible - enemies skipping the ladder and just appearing in a corner choking you. I know they are trying to keep the aggro and intensity up, but I don't like cheap shots. I don't mind enemies spawning in from outside of your accessible environment then walking in and I prefer to have the chance to react first than just getting jumped and choked. 

But overall, the goods far outweigh the negatives in this title, and I am glad I was able to play it. This should have set a standard for how to remake a beloved classic - Looking at you Metal Gear Solid 3, still the same 20 year old game with new graphics. Well I just won't buy those, only excellence drives my purchases, and this is it.

This game is perfection. From the story and characters to the world design and gameplay, it’s hard to find anything to dislike.

From a narrative perspective, the story is engaging and well-paced, supported by characters who feel well developed. Leon Kennedy is an iconic character, and playing as him is just really cool. Ashley is peak.

The environments and levels feel incredibly atmospheric, and the game uses modern graphics well to create highly immersive environments. Each area is detailed, visually amazing, and thematically consistent, while still offering enough variety to keep progression interesting.

Gameplay is where I feel the remake truly excels. Movement and gunplay feel smooth and just a lot of fun to pilot. Puzzles also actually feel like puzzles without being frustrating. The game’s design accommodates varying playstyles, whether you’re doing a casual run, completing every in-game challenge, or playing on harder difficulties where every mistake matters. For those who’ve played the RE2 Remake previously, it doesn’t follow that game’s blueprint, as you’re not constantly backtracking, which keeps the experience refreshing since you’re mostly encountering new areas. The game also offers a wide range of bosses (rather than 3 variants of the same boss), each unique from one another, which helps keep major encounters exciting.

Compared to the original RE4, this remake improves on nearly everything that made the first game iconic. That said, it’s a remake, not a remaster, and therefore isn’t a 1:1 recreation of the original. The game makes slight tweaks to certain story beats and expands on chapters and levels from the original, all of which are well done, resulting in a narrative that feels fuller and gives you better mileage for your playtime. The remake also features darker atmospheres and stronger horror themes, making it feel more aligned with the rest of the Resident Evil series, though it does lose a bit of the original’s lighter, campier charm. Leon is more serious here, which works on its own, but I do miss some of his personality from the original.

Overall, this is an amazing remake of an iconic original, and Capcom has delivered what I would consider the best example of how to modernize a game while still respecting what made it special.

In order to understand what went fundamentally wrong with RE4make we should first briefly revisit what defined the original and what it’s remembered and still played for.

The original back in 2005 was revolutionary - it established the third person shooter genre and redefined the survival horror one. It placed a particular emphasis on combat, with an integral part of that being tactical and responsive gunplay. Every weapon had an identity and shooting any part of an enemy came with distinct advantages - whether slowing them down, disarming them or blowing up lit dynamite, taking out their allies in the process. Loot and ammo dropping from every enemy and even crows and chicken encouraged you - for the very first time in Resident Evil franchise - to engage with combat mechanics instead of avoiding combat to conserve ammunition, as it was customary for the classic games.

Meanwhile RE4make reuses the combat system from the remake of Resident Evil 2. The slow and methodical gunplay that makes you wait for the reticle to close after every shot; the punishing spread and recoil that discourages firing a submachine gun other than in short bursts; the bullet-spongy enemies that barely even flinch and make it feel like your guns are shooting blanks; the comically overpowered yet ever-breaking knives leaving you defenceless - all that worked well in RE2, portraying the character as vulnerable and presenting even a single zombie as a real threat, encouraging the player to avoid combat rather than engage in it.

Needless to say, it doesn’t work here. As a result, the remake plays like RE2 with decorations from RE4. This weird mixture of different concepts creates a game that doesn’t know what it wants from you - to engage in inconsistent, unfair and unfun combat with little room for tactical gunplay, the enemies that will stunlock you while attacking relentlessly and a knife that’s better than a rocket launcher; or to remove your gear and force you to make use of its new feature, the stealth mechanics. The latter is an afterthought that achieves nothing other than to break the pacing of the game and take away from its combat focus. The 2005 revolution has not been improved upon, but instead was treated as if never happened. The laser sight - arguably one of the original’s most notable additions to combat - while technically still present as a side quest reward you need to grind for, can now only be attached to a couple of weaker pistols.

As far as the story and atmosphere are concerned, the original is best characterized as an unpretentious B-movie. It was full of cheesy one-liners, silly dialogues and goofy fan service “features”, like looking up Ashley’s skirt. The game was very self-aware and did everything to prevent you from treating itself too seriously. It did not really try to be a horror either - acknowledging the fact that when a game gives you a machine gun, the only thing you can be scared of is running out of ammo. As a whole, it all worked well to give the original its unique vibe and identity.

The remake, however, goes out of its way to present itself as dead serious. The surroundings and ambience try their best to create a dark, ominous atmosphere. Unnecessary and excessive even by RE standards graphical violence in your face including mutilated corpses and elaborate death animations as well as an annoying mandatory horror segment make it feel like a love letter to Village instead of the original. There’s no longer much room for based light-hearted comedy in this new game, and drastic changes to characters and dialogues are emblematic of that. The feminine “damsel in distress” Ashley is gone - replaced by a cringe “strong and independent” Ashley instead. The president did not equip his daughter with ballistics this time round, while a modern take on Ashley’s lingerie with 4k textures, ray tracing, DLSS and HDR is obviously out of discussion. She now calls herself “master of unlocking”, no longer offers Leon “overtime” and (following in RE3make’s footsteps) wears an ugly skort. Ada’s red dress was likewise taken away from her in favour of a sweater. Hunnigan is now overly professional rather than casual and flirty. And Leon is now suffering from PTSD one minute and spitting one-liners the next one - unsure of his role in this brave new world. Of course, they did not stop at the tone and character design: the game no longer features many dialogues, a number of areas, weapons and bosses, nor any of the additional content RE4 used to have.

As a result, in RE4make the overly serious vibe strangely coexists with the few remaining one-liners and ridiculous enemies like a giant fish. It comes across as a game “gone woke” and somehow manages to be even less faithful to the original than the remake of RE3 - which, to be fair, at least preserved the tone and spirit of its namesake. The things that made the original so fun are just not here anymore, being “reimagined”, censored or sterilized. In fact, RE4make feels like a completely different game that just so happens to share a bunch of names with the original.

Is this different game at least great as far as modern games are concerned? Unfortunately, this is not the case either. There is nothing here that would bring novelty to the genre or, indeed, even justify the existence of this remake. The only additions to the usual formula are side quests (boring busywork tasks with little variety like “kill 3 rats” and “shoot 6 medallions”) and lootboxes giving you rare and epic charms to boost your stats. The unsatisfying and inconsistent gunplay does not belong here and is not fit for purpose. Continuing the trend set by RE3make level design is full of cramped, claustrophobic corridors as if created to work around PS1-era hardware limitations. The voice acting is sad and uninspired, oftentimes missing its “acting” part. The level of self-plagiarism here is staggering, evident of creative stagnation in the absence of great minds like Shinji Mikami: if you played RE2 Remake or Village (ironically, itself a derivative of RE4) - you pretty much played this one as well.

Of course, a review should not only be concerned with the question of how good the game is, but also how good it is for the asking price. And I see two problems here. First of all, it’s priced $60 - higher than any of Capcom’s previous remakes. And frankly, it’s a big ask considering there’s no additional content. The second, arguably even bigger issue is the nonexistent regional pricing. For example, as a Ukrainian gamer as of time of this review I can get Cyberpunk for $25, and Hogwarts Legacy for mere $20. Meanwhile Capcom expected me to pay some $55 - about full price.

I’d also like to mention what I can only describe as aggressive monetization. You see, the progression once again follows the RE3R formula - the higher levels of difficulty are simply brutal and are envisioned to be tackled not as much with skill but rather overpowered weaponry from previous runs (Professional is clearly balanced around infinite rocket launcher). Preorder bonus trinkets actually give you gameplay advantages like more gold and ammo crafted, effectively making Hardcore difficulty not-so-hardcore. Meanwhile Deluxe Edition adds treasures that simply don’t exist in the game otherwise as well as guns that are all-round better than those you can find in the beginning - and you can now even upgrade them! I grew up playing RE4 on the gamecube. Spent easily 1000+ hours on it doing lots of challenge runs and speedruns because i just loved the shit out of that game. Approaching this game with some of those tactics still in my head 20 years later may have tainted my experience. I played this with a controller, which was probably a big mistake.

1. Limited enemy reaction to damage - staggering enemies is either RNG based or hp based. Old game, you shoot a guy in the head or knees, he staggers and you can melee. this was critical for early crowd control when your primary tool was the pistol. Now in the remake, I regularly shoot enemies in the head 3 times without getting a stagger, sometimes twice without even a hitstun. Effect here is likely by design since it forces more usage of shotgun and grenades in order to handle crowds, but making generic enemies eat bullets to the face with no reaction feels awful, especially since this was a huge selling point for the original game. Maybe the short-term solution is to bench the pistol?

2. Crosshair depth - old game rooted you in place when shooting, and you aimed with a laser pointer. Now you have classic shooter crosshairs with variable spread etc, but you don't have a laser projection from your weapon, if enemies get too close your ability to hit them greatly decreases since your aiming function sources the camera, not your character model.
 
3. Lack of sound cues. This is probably the worst one for me, and I doubt I can mod it away. Maybe I leaned on these too much back in the day, but having an enemy grab/chop/stab you from behind with zero sound cue that you're being flanked was very unpleasant, especially with how the game forces you to tunnel-vision on the targets in front of you with the aim camera and fov zoom. Having to shoot the guy in front of you 3+ times in the head while being unable to hear the ladder being placed behind you or getting a sound cue from a flanking foe really highlights how they made the game worse.

And I'm only two hours in. I have no idea how this game is being reviewed so well when its objectively worse than the original. I hope I can aggressively mod to mitigate these issues, or faster aiming with m&kb could make issue #2 more tolerable.

In the original game, combat was a relatively slow and calculated process that spawned an entire genre - juggling enemies with the ammo and tools provided with reliable enemy hitstun and stagger, and that proverbial boat was rocked when a parasite head or a thicker enemy type appeared - this changed your priorities, forced a brief retreat, reposition, or weapon swap. This design spawned an entire goddamn genre.  Now your boat gets rocked as soon as more than two enemies are in your line of sight, not to mention the silent/invisible enemies behind you due to lack of basic sound design. Maybe this is more survival-horror-y? I find bullet sponge enemies in this game tedious, especially when there's a wall of them in front of you.

I can only fathom the overwhelmingly positive reviews are due to lack of experience with the original game, or if m&kb really fixes everything. The original was a vastly superior experience - and Salazar had a nice hat that I now have to mod in. This remake, so far, feels very small time. Huge disappointment.

p.s. i would give away instant grab-breaks and the upgradable combat knife for the old game's unbreakable basic knife without a moments hesitation.

In order to understand what went fundamentally wrong with RE4make we should first briefly revisit what defined the original and what it’s remembered and still played for.

The original back in 2005 was revolutionary - it established the third person shooter genre and redefined the survival horror one. It placed a particular emphasis on combat, with an integral part of that being tactical and responsive gunplay. Every weapon had an identity and shooting any part of an enemy came with distinct advantages - whether slowing them down, disarming them or blowing up lit dynamite, taking out their allies in the process. Loot and ammo dropping from every enemy and even crows and chicken encouraged you - for the very first time in Resident Evil franchise - to engage with combat mechanics instead of avoiding combat to conserve ammunition, as it was customary for the classic games.

Meanwhile RE4make reuses the combat system from the remake of Resident Evil 2. The slow and methodical gunplay that makes you wait for the reticle to close after every shot; the punishing spread and recoil that discourages firing a submachine gun other than in short bursts; the bullet-spongy enemies that barely even flinch and make it feel like your guns are shooting blanks; the comically overpowered yet ever-breaking knives leaving you defenceless - all that worked well in RE2, portraying the character as vulnerable and presenting even a single zombie as a real threat, encouraging the player to avoid combat rather than engage in it.

Needless to say, it doesn’t work here. As a result, the remake plays like RE2 with decorations from RE4. This weird mixture of different concepts creates a game that doesn’t know what it wants from you - to engage in inconsistent, unfair and unfun combat with little room for tactical gunplay, the enemies that will stunlock you while attacking relentlessly and a knife that’s better than a rocket launcher; or to remove your gear and force you to make use of its new feature, the stealth mechanics. The latter is an afterthought that achieves nothing other than to break the pacing of the game and take away from its combat focus. The 2005 revolution has not been improved upon, but instead was treated as if never happened. The laser sight - arguably one of the original’s most notable additions to combat - while technically still present as a side quest reward you need to grind for, can now only be attached to a couple of weaker pistols.

As far as the story and atmosphere are concerned, the original is best characterized as an unpretentious B-movie. It was full of cheesy one-liners, silly dialogues and goofy fan service “features”, like looking up Ashley’s skirt. The game was very self-aware and did everything to prevent you from treating itself too seriously. It did not really try to be a horror either - acknowledging the fact that when a game gives you a machine gun, the only thing you can be scared of is running out of ammo. As a whole, it all worked well to give the original its unique vibe and identity.

The remake, however, goes out of its way to present itself as dead serious. The surroundings and ambience try their best to create a dark, ominous atmosphere. Unnecessary and excessive even by RE standards graphical violence in your face including mutilated corpses and elaborate death animations as well as an annoying mandatory horror segment make it feel like a love letter to Village instead of the original. There’s no longer much room for based light-hearted comedy in this new game, and drastic changes to characters and dialogues are emblematic of that. The feminine “damsel in distress” Ashley is gone - replaced by a cringe “strong and independent” Ashley instead. The president did not equip his daughter with ballistics this time round, while a modern take on Ashley’s lingerie with 4k textures, ray tracing, DLSS and HDR is obviously out of discussion. She now calls herself “master of unlocking”, no longer offers Leon “overtime” and (following in RE3make’s footsteps) wears an ugly skort. Ada’s red dress was likewise taken away from her in favour of a sweater. Hunnigan is now overly professional rather than casual and flirty. And Leon is now suffering from PTSD one minute and spitting one-liners the next one - unsure of his role in this brave new world. Of course, they did not stop at the tone and character design: the game no longer features many dialogues, a number of areas, weapons and bosses, nor any of the additional content RE4 used to have.

As a result, in RE4make the overly serious vibe strangely coexists with the few remaining one-liners and ridiculous enemies like a giant fish. It comes across as a game “gone woke” and somehow manages to be even less faithful to the original than the remake of RE3 - which, to be fair, at least preserved the tone and spirit of its namesake. The things that made the original so fun are just not here anymore, being “reimagined”, censored or sterilized. In fact, RE4make feels like a completely different game that just so happens to share a bunch of names with the original.

Is this different game at least great as far as modern games are concerned? Unfortunately, this is not the case either. There is nothing here that would bring novelty to the genre or, indeed, even justify the existence of this remake. The only additions to the usual formula are side quests (boring busywork tasks with little variety like “kill 3 rats” and “shoot 6 medallions”) and lootboxes giving you rare and epic charms to boost your stats. The unsatisfying and inconsistent gunplay does not belong here and is not fit for purpose. Continuing the trend set by RE3make level design is full of cramped, claustrophobic corridors as if created to work around PS1-era hardware limitations. The voice acting is sad and uninspired, oftentimes missing its “acting” part. The level of self-plagiarism here is staggering, evident of creative stagnation in the absence of great minds like Shinji Mikami: if you played RE2 Remake or Village (ironically, itself a derivative of RE4) - you pretty much played this one as well.

Of course, a review should not only be concerned with the question of how good the game is, but also how good it is for the asking price. And I see two problems here. First of all, it’s priced $60 - higher than any of Capcom’s previous remakes. And frankly, it’s a big ask considering there’s no additional content. The second, arguably even bigger issue is the nonexistent regional pricing. For example, as a Ukrainian gamer as of time of this review I can get Cyberpunk for $25, and Hogwarts Legacy for mere $20. Meanwhile Capcom expected me to pay some $55 - about full price.

I’d also like to mention what I can only describe as aggressive monetization. You see, the progression once again follows the RE3R formula - the higher levels of difficulty are simply brutal and are envisioned to be tackled not as much with skill but rather overpowered weaponry from previous runs (Professional is clearly balanced around infinite rocket launcher). Preorder bonus trinkets actually give you gameplay advantages like more gold and ammo crafted, effectively making Hardcore difficulty not-so-hardcore. Meanwhile Deluxe Edition adds treasures that simply don’t exist in the game otherwise as well as guns that are all-round better than those you can find in the beginning - and you can now even upgrade them! It all feels very pay-to-win in a singleplayer game. I imagine RE4make was designed as a cash cow and will get All Rewards Unlocked and many other DLC in the future.

TL;DR: RE2make and Village had a baby, allowed it to pick its gender and gave it a famous name just because. It is not another revolution for the genre - it’s merely a corridor shooter with yellow paint of handholding everywhere. Hard skip if you’re a fan of the original, grab on sale if you couldn’t get enough of Capcom’s recent games on RE Engine and wanted more of the same.

This is a negative review simply to lower it from it's current 97% positive score, as I do not in any scenario believe this is a 97% game. 
I completed the game on Hardcore mode for my first playthrough, and went into the launch of this game with a lot of excitement being such a huge fan of the original. However, by the end, while it was certainly an experience, it is overall a hollow interpretation of the original masterpiece in survival horror. 

- Ada is horrible, and while this is mainly due to her voice actress being horrible, it also has to do with the fact that they are not subtle with her at all. That's a bad thing. The original handled her better in that regard in making her classy AND sexy, but not making her seem like a complete hoe either. We already know Ada is hot. We don't need Chapter 10 to open up with a straight @$$ shot to prove it. And... just hire a new actress please, that was SO bad man. (btw, go get the mod on Nexus that overrides it with a new one that sounds a LOT better)
- Leon is worse in this game than in the original overall. He is NOT bad in this game, don't get me wrong, but they totally changed how he acts in a variety of situations. All of the dude's dorky coolness got replaced with edgy coolness, which I would not say is necessarily a good thing. The OG Leon is always going to be best, but this still isn't terrible. 
- The one liners of Leon's get their own section, as a LOT of them are gone and replaced with new ones. This also is bad, as the old ones were literal gold. The new ones, once again, are fine, but Leon is a worse character for it. 
- The game feels uninspired at times. A lot of Ashley's dialogue feels like it was written by AI, it's just VERY generic. The gameplay, while engaging and fun, is also very generic. You find a lot of other games that do exactly what this game does on a gameplay level, and that definitely takes a bit of points away compared to the very unique gameplay of the original. All of Ada's dialogue definitely falls here in this category as well. 
- Mercenaries mode, what HAPPENED to you?! Why would they put a limit on the enemies you kill? Why? Why would they do that? That is so stupid. It's a fun mode overall, but dang. 

Now, while I did say all of those bad things about the game, there were good things about the game that I thoroughly enjoyed. 
- Krauser. They did him SO well. I was genuinely speechless by the time the fight with him was finished. 
- Luis. While I did find him more annoying here than I did in the original at first, he grew on me a lot, and didn't feel like he overstayed his welcome. 
- The atmosphere of this game is VERY well done. It was haunting going through this game, seeing all of the environments for the first time, and of course fighting through the WAVES of enemies infected with Las Plagas. This is probably the strongest point of this entire game. 

It is a solid game, and I had a lot of fun with it. However, this is certainly no masterpiece. I mean, it can't be, it's just a recycled product from the past with a fresh coat of paint and 75% of the charm gone. Just play the OG, it's better in every way, and WAY cheaper. Also, the OG has a WAY better Mercenaries mode too, so have fun with that.
